Yes but is it the antipsychotics both typical and atypical ones  which cause them

Well its generally the atypical antipsychotics that have a risk of diabetes and other metabolic imbalances. Lithium can certainly cause weight gain. I remember that being a problem when I was on it. With other mood stabilizers it varies. Right now the mood stabilizer I am on Clonidine can cause weight gain but the way I avoid that is to not snack on things that are unhealthy and to drink flavored seltzer water instead of soda or any other beverage with sugar. I don't buy them and they are not in the house when I want to snack as well. And to excercise which in my case means taking a full brisk walk daily. If its too cold to go out I ride the excercise bike. And even with the atypical antipsychotics the risk of diabetes is not automatic. A friend of mine had pre-diabetes from Abilify and he went on a healthy diet and lost 40 pounds and that passed. If someone needs general weight loss or diet advice their doctor can usually advise them. If it becomes severe and a medication change doesn't help it then its best to see a nutritionist. First find out what medication your psychiatrist will prescribe and what the risk of weight gain is and see from there.

They key to eating healthy and keeping insulin resistance under control is portion size. This will actually also help with mood as limiting foods or cutting out too many carbs can actually cause your body and mind to stop functioning properly. A healthy diet is not one that excludes any food, but a diet that balances all things. For example, high carb foods should not be 100% restricted from your diet. Carbohydrates such as starch, fructose, lactose, sucrose is our fuel. Protein helps build muscle and holds important nutrients but is not a fuel. Fiber is non-digestable and mainly helps with feeling full / clean sweeping the digestive system. Healthy fats are also important to good health, such as nuts and olive oil, etc.So, you can have cake or whatever, but just limit. If you want to follow a healthy diet then you should count your carbohydrates properly. In order to do this (if you don't already know,) take your label and subtract the fiber from the total carbohydrates. Ignore the part that says sugar (this is already included in the total carbohydrates.) You should have 45-60 carbohydrates per meal and 15 for a snack. But, if you already eat more carbs than that slowly reduce your intake or you'll just go crazy.Hope this helps. :D

Ironically, I found this study today about diet and mood. Although these people were not bipolar it found that after 8 weeks, people on a low carb diet did improve mood. However, after 8 weeks their mood declined. They were on the diet for 1year. People on a high carb diet had the same initial improvement in mood but this improvement continued over the course of the year.http://health.msn.com/nutrition/articlepage.aspx?cp-documentid=100248252&GT1=31036This is, of course, only a small study and only the beginning. But I think further study will show that it is better to limit portion sizes in all areas of a diet and not just one area.Of course, just like anything, you should consult your doctor before changing your diet.
